author: By Yan Zhuang
title: ‘Different Standards’: The Struggle of Indigenous Journalists in Australia
description: The departure of the TV host Stan Grant has set off a conversation about race and racism in the country’s media industry.
content: This week, I wrote about the conversation about race and racism in the Australian media industry that had been set off by the announcement from Stan Grant that he would step back from his television hosting duties. Mr. Grant, one of Australia’s most high-profile journalists, said that he and his family had received “relentless” racial abuse after he spoke about colonial-era violence as part of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation’s coverage of the coronation of King Charles III.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Our TV critic recommends a beautiful finale (that isn’t “Succession” or “Barry”), a charming comedy and a lush dinosaur docu-series.
content: ‘Somebody Somewhere’When to watch: Sunday at 11:33 p.m., on HBO.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Stop Us if You’ve Heard This Before: The A’s Have a Stadium Deal
description: From faking a rainout at a World Series game to a possum in a television booth, the Athletics have rarely been happy at home. Will Las Vegas be the answer?
content: It was announced this week that the Athletics, at long last, had come to an agreement with a group of politicians to build a new stadium for the club, which has been stuck in an outdated facility for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Jet Door Opens in Flight, but Plane Lands Safely
description: A man was arrested on suspicion of unlocking an emergency exit on an Asiana Airlines flight in South Korea when it was about 700 feet off the ground.
content: The unexpected opening of an emergency exit door on an Asiana Airlines plane making its landing on Friday in Daegu, South Korea, left passengers shaken, and nine of them were hospitalized after they experienced difficulty breathing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Hundreds of Thousands Have Lost Medicaid Coverage Since Pandemic Protections Expired
description: As states begin to drop people from their Medicaid programs, early data shows that many recipients are losing their coverage for procedural reasons.
content: Hundreds of thousands of low-income Americans have lost Medicaid coverage in recent weeks as part of a sprawling unwinding of a pandemic-era policy that prohibited states from removing people from the program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: This Little-Known Pandemic-Era Tax Credit Has Become a Magnet for Fraud
description: The Employee Retention Credit has spawned a cottage industry of firms claiming to help businesses get stimulus funds, often in violation of federal rules.
content: In early February, federal prosecutors in Utah accused Zachary Bassett and Mason Warr of cheating the United States government out of millions of dollars. The accounting firm they operated had submitted more than 1,000 fraudulent tax forms to the Internal Revenue Service on behalf of businesses trying to claim pandemic-era stimulus funds, the prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: If a Divided Germany Could Enter NATO, Why Not Ukraine?
description: West Germany joined NATO in 1955, choosing security over immediate territorial integrity. Some suggest the same path could be the best guarantee for Ukraine.
content: Though peace seems distant, the United States and Europe are debating how to guarantee Ukraine’s security once the fighting with Russia stops, even without a total victory by either side. West Germany may provide a model, a precedent for admitting a divided country into NATO.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: This $50,000 Watch Kills Its Wearers by Slicing Their Wrists
description: Our columnist on “Death Watch,” “Going Zero” and other pulse-pounding summer novels.
content: “Fortunately, the world is thick with fools,” the pretentious artist Watanabe declares as he unveils his latest provocation: Cassius Seven, a $50,000 watch that cannot be removed — and that is designed to eventually kill its wearers by slitting their wrists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Vowel-less Crossword
description: All consonants are welcome in this outrageous challenge by Evan Kalish.
content: VOWEL-LESS CROSSWORD — This puzzle is the latest installment of a variety grid that comes around roughly once a year. It’s also Evan Kalish’s third such construction and a ton of fun. I am definitely not getting better as a solver, because there are really no developable skills or strategy I can think of that would help me. So it’s more likely that this is a deducible, entertaining set of entries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: $38.8 Billion in U.S. Treasury? For These Billionaires, That’s Nothing.
description: The cash balance at the Treasury Department is now lower than the net worth of some of the world’s richest people.
content: The Treasury Department said its cash balance fell to $38.8 billion as of Thursday, as the United States inched toward running out of cash to pay its bills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: How the New ‘Little Mermaid’ Goes Back ‘Under the Sea’
description: The director Rob Marshall discusses his take on the musical number featuring Daveed Diggs as Sebastian and Halle Bailey as Ariel.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Roasted Potato Salad, Crisp-Edged Smash Burgers and Smoked Cabbage Slaw
description: With straight-up rhubarb pie and double strawberry shortcakes, to take full advantage of peak spring produce.
content: Good morning. It’s Memorial Day weekend already? Time’s a flat circle, a record spinning, always and forever returning to its start. Summer holidays, Labor Day, the rush of early fall — it’s all coming around faster and faster. Gone are those slow, languid, scary-boring days of the pandemic past, when everyone was soaking beans and waiting for the sourdough to proof. We’ll be testing Thanksgiving recipes soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Pols
title: To Be Enjoyed in a State of Repose, Preferably Near Water
description: These five novels go well with sand, sunscreen and hot afternoons. (Landlocked on a rainy day? That works, too.)
content: There’s a scene around the halfway mark of the latest novel by the perennial best seller Elin Hilderbrand, THE FIVE-STAR WEEKEND (Little, Brown, 384 pp., $30), in which five women engage in a sacred ritual of beach vacations: shopping. The connection between them is the recently widowed Hollis Shaw, who invited four women from different eras of her life (high school, college, minivan life and midlife) to her fabulous Nantucket summer home to celebrate friendship and, ultimately, to help Hollis, the food influencer, move into the next phase of life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: How Extreme Heat Causes Cascading Crises
description: Power grids and hospitals can be overwhelmed, but there are fixes.
content: Extreme heat can bring on some extremely dangerous feedback loops for American hospitals and clinics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Ice Spice Joins Taylor Swift’s ‘Karma,’ and 9 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Dua Lipa, Water From Your Eyes, Ichiko Aoba and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: A Union That Felt Like ‘a Love Letter to Black Culture’
description: Tristan Thompson and Tyla Wade’s passion for their community was the inspiration for their podcast “Black Love is Resistance” and their wedding celebration that featured mostly Black vendors.
content: “Black love is a form of resistance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Despite High-Level Guarantees, Time Is Running Out to Avoid a Default
description: With a June 5 deadline looming, there is much to be done to prevent the default that leaders of both parties said would never happen.
content: Senator Mitch McConnell had a message for Americans growing increasingly worried that the economy is going to crash if the federal debt ceiling is not raised: Just chill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Silvana Paternostro
title: Colombia’s Peace-Whisperer Makes Plenty of Enemies
description: Leyner Palacios’s push for dialogue, forgiveness and reconciliation has made him the face of peace in Colombia — and subjected him to death threats.
content: CARTAGENA, Colombia — For a champion of peace, Leyner Palacios faces a lot death threats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Do You Have What It Takes to Be Kendall Roy’s Assistant?
description: In “Succession,” Jess quits, and Kerry was in tears. What is it actually like to be an assistant to the ultra wealthy?
content: Jess Jordan, Kendall Roy’s assistant in the HBO drama “Succession,” is finished with the permanent headache that is the Roy family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: Hyundai and LG Plan $4.3 Billion Battery Plant in Georgia
description: The facility is the second battery project under development in the state by Hyundai Motor Group and may bring 3,000 jobs.
content: Hyundai Motor Group and LG Energy Solutions announced plans on Thursday to build a $4.3 billion electric vehicle battery plant in Georgia, the latest clean energy facility to come to the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: ‘Primary Trust’ Review: Sipping Mai Tais, Until Bitter Reality Knocks
description: In Eboni Booth’s new play, William Jackson Harper performs with astonishing vulnerability as a man alone and adrift.
content: Maybe you’ve seen him tucked into the corner of a dive bar, muttering to himself now and then, empty glasses multiplying on his table. And perhaps you’ve thought — though, it’s just as likely you haven’t — What’s up with that guy?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: unanimous
description: This word has appeared in 312 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word unanimous has appeared in 312 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 15 in “Soccer’s Perpetual President: Why Gianni Infantino Can’t Lose” by Tariq Panja:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Why Does Day Drinking Feel Different?
description: A buzz in the sun can hit harder than dinnertime drinks. Experts shed light on the science.
content: A poolside margarita, a frosty beer at a Memorial Day barbecue — summer, you could argue, is made for a cold drink on a hot day.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tina Turner, a Queen of Rock ’n’ Roll Covers
description: The musician, who died on Wednesday at 83, was a radical interpreter of other artists’ material. Listen here.
content: As the great Tina Turner told it in the wrenching 2021 documentary “Tina,” when she began to envision a solo career finally liberated from her abusive ex-husband, Ike, in the early ’80s, she told her new manager, Roger Davies, “My dream is to be the first Black rock ’n’ roll singer to pack places like the Stones.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Bullard and Larry Shapiro
title: Will Lawmakers Sacrifice Our Health and Safety to Get a Debt Ceiling Deal?
description: A crucial part of the clean energy transition is swept up in the high-pressure negotiations happening in Washington.
content: If the United States can figure out how to quickly build more clean energy, places like Port Arthur, Texas, and Lake Charles, Louisiana, may have the most to gain. These communities have for decades shouldered a disproportionate burden of fossil fuel pollution and residents paid dearly with their health. With fewer oil, gas and petrochemical facilities, the air in these communities could get a lot cleaner very soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Contributions to College Savings Plans Pick Up as Inflation Eases
description: Deposits into 529 savings accounts fell last fall and early this year. But experts say the stock market recovery is helping to attract more money.
content: Contributions to 529 college savings programs fell late last year and early this year, according to industry data, as consumers saved less overall and battled high inflation. But contributions appeared to be rebounding in recent months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Luckerson
title: How Greenwood Grew a Thriving Black Economy
description: W.E.B. Du Bois saw the key to Black prosperity in places like Tulsa, where Black residents patronized Black stores. Even today it serves as a model.
content: When W.E.B. Du Bois visited the Greenwood District of Tulsa, Okla., in early 1921, he, like so many others, was impressed by what he found. The famed intellectual had been on the road for weeks on a Southern lecture tour. In his travel diary, he wrote of brutal lynchings and brutalization that were as old as the nation itself — older, in fact.  What grabbed Du Bois’s attention was what his people were accomplishing despite it. “One notes all through the south, with some exception, the new hope and power of the colored folk,” he wrote in his diary. “It is not any increased faith in the white people — quite the contrary — it is a distinct sense of their own ability.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: ‘Yellowjackets’ Season 2 Finale Recap: Fade Out
description: A new leader is anointed. Decades later, the Yellowjackets still aren’t free of the consequences.
content: For Natalie Scatorccio, this season finale of “Yellowjackets” is both a coronation and a funeral.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Hughes
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Evan Gershkovich, the American reporter Russia accuses of spying, appeals the extension of his detention.
description: Already jailed for two months on charges for which Russia has provided no evidence, Mr. Gershkovich has been ordered to remain in prison for three more.
content: Evan Gershkovich, the Wall Street Journal reporter jailed in Russia on espionage charges, has appealed a court decision earlier this week that extended his detention by more than three months, The Journal confirmed on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alida Becker
title: During the Dog Days, Escape to the Old Days
description: These books rewind time, depositing readers in the Cumbrian countryside, coastal Maine, rural Wyoming and beyond.
content: Summer reading should be completely escapist, sending you to places and times you’re reluctant to leave. The best historical novels do just that, and this season there are plenty to choose from.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: They Knew Little About Oysters. Now They Have a Farm With 2 Million.
description: Stefanie Bassett and Elizabeth Peeples left their city lives behind to raise mollusks.
content: The Little Ram Oyster Co., a farm of 2 million oysters on the North Fork of Long Island, started with a Groupon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Japanese Moon Lander Crashed Because of a Software Glitch
description: Ispace was aiming to become the first private company to land on the surface of the moon, but lost contact with its robotic spacecraft in late April.
content: A software glitch caused a Japanese robotic spacecraft to misjudge its altitude as it attempted to land on the moon last month leading to its crash, an investigation has revealed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘The Machine’ Review: A Hard-Partying Comedian Pays for His Sins
description: In a movie extrapolated from one of his stand-up bits, Bert Kreischer is dragged to Russia to face a gory but still comedic reckoning.
content: The star of this picture, Bert Kreischer, is one of those popular stand-up comedians who’s not zeitgeist-adjacent enough to generate much in the way of think pieces or buzz. But in the late 1990s, as a student at Florida State University, he was the subject of a Rolling Stone magazine profile that named him “the top partyer at the Number One Party School in the country.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Luke Broadwater
title: Behind the Scenes: Midnight Calls and Marathon Meetings, Night After Night
description: What day is it, anyway? As talks drag on, the situation is getting painful for everyone from the negotiators to the tourists on Capitol Hill.
content: On Capitol Hill, the delicate talks to avert default on the government’s debts this week took place over middle-of-the-night video calls, marathon meetings in an opulent conference room, and at least one early morning bike ride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: Is It Legal to Sleep Outside in New York? Yes and No.
description: A “Homeless Bill of Rights” that could become law on Saturday aims to clarify legal issues for homeless people, including whether they can camp outdoors. But the rules are anything but clear.
content: The five words tucked into a bill listing the rights of homeless people in New York City seem straightforward enough:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: Erdogan Amassed Power Over 20 Years, Leveraging Crisis After Crisis
description: Turkey’s leader faced a criminal conviction, mass protests and a coup. Instead of hurting or ending his political career, they helped him accumulate ever more control.
content: From mayor to lawmaker and prime minister to president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan rose through the ranks to Turkey’s highest positions and then made them his own, bringing the country over the course of 20 years closer to one-man rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Real Threat to Freedom Is Coming From the States
description: We have a long history with various forms of sub-national authoritarianism.
content: Across the country, we are seeing sharp new limits on the rights and privileges of Americans. And despite a national mythology that ties the threat of tyranny to the machinations of a distant, central government, the actual threat to American freedom is coming from the states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Tom Sawyer, Congressman Who Challenged Census Undercount, Dies at 77
description: A Democrat from Ohio, he said the 1990 population data missed more than two million Black Americans and shortchanged the nation’s older cities.
content: Tom Sawyer, an eight-term Democratic congressman from Ohio whose concern that the 1990 census had missed more than two million Black Americans spurred the federal government to improve its subsequent population counts, died on May 20 in a nursing facility in Akron. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Sedition Sentence for Oath Keepers Leader Marks Moment of Accountability
description: The 18 years in prison given to Stewart Rhodes for a rarely charged crime underscored the lengths to which the Justice Department and the courts have gone in addressing the assault on the Capitol.
content: A few hours after Stewart Rhodes, the leader of the Oath Keepers militia, was sentenced on Thursday to 18 years in prison for his role in a seditious conspiracy to instigate the pro-Trump violence of Jan. 6, Matthew M. Graves, the federal prosecutor who has overseen the government’s investigation of the Capitol attack, released a statement with a fact that underscored the landmark nature of the moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Dortmund, Bayern and the Chance of a Lifetime
description: A Dortmund victory on Saturday will end Bayern Munich’s streak of 10 straight titles. The prospect of a new champion should be a cause of celebration beyond a single city.
content: The requests had started to flow almost as soon as the final whistle blew last Sunday. All through Monday, they came in great torrents to members of the Borussia Dortmund staff, to the club’s executives, to the players themselves. They came from family, of course, and from friends, and from friends of friends, and acquaintances and colleagues and that guy you met in that restaurant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Our Quick Take on the Oath Keepers Trial and the Day’s Top Stories
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: As Pressure Mounts on Everton, Premier League Applies Some of Its Own
description: A club’s battle to avoid relegation is being shadowed by an investigation into its spending, and nudges to announce a resolution before next season.
content: Everything is clear at the top of the Premier League.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dara Lind
title: The U.S. Keeps Telling People to Come the ‘Right Way.’ They’re Listening.
description: The American asylum lottery is, shockingly, a rare border success story.
content: America now has an asylum lottery.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ron DeSantis’s Entry Into the Republican Race
description: Assessing Ron DeSantis’s candidacy. Also: Not debating Donald Trump; trans people; regulating A.I.; finances during divorce; musing about “the best.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Chau Doan
title: A Video Mocking a Vietnamese Official’s Lavish Meal Has Landed Its Maker in Prison
description: A powerful Communist official ate a gold-encrusted steak in London. An activist who poked fun at the excess was sentenced to more than five years.
content: This is a tale of two meals and two men named Lam. It begins with a joke and ends with a prison sentence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Sophia Lanman and Rowan Niemisto
title: The Surgeon General’s Social Media Warning and A.I.’s Existential Risks
description: Plus, Kevin and Casey react to this week’s tech headlines.
content: The U.S. surgeon general, Dr. Vivek Murthy, says social media poses a “profound risk of harm” to young people. Why do some in the tech industry disagree?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kodé
title: Are the Hamptons Still Hip?
description: The summer resort has lost its cool among younger people who are turned off by housing rules, housing costs and the culture of conspicuous wealth.
content: For years, the Hamptons were a hot summer destination for young, up-and-coming New Yorkers and the old and new moneyed alike. It was a place to see and be seen. Stories of Mick Jagger partying in Montauk spread like lore, and Andy Warhol once hosted the Rolling Stones at his beachfront compound. It wasn’t uncommon for young college graduates in the city to save up and pool together to rent a summer house and get a taste of the glamour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Celine Dion Cancels the Remainder of Her World Tour
description: The pop star, who announced in December that she was suffering from a rare neurological condition, said she was “working really hard to build back my strength.”
content: The powerhouse pop superstar Celine Dion announced Friday morning on social media that she was canceling the remainder of her Courage World Tour through April 2024 in order to focus on her recovery from a rare autoimmune and neurological disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conrad Gregory
title: ‘That’s Why I Picked a Younger Man’
description: My mother’s second husband wasn’t supposed to die before she did. And neither was I.
content: The day after Thanksgiving, my mother called, worried I was going to die. I had mistakenly told her that I had heartburn, so she left a long voice mail reminding me of how my father had heartburn before he died of a heart attack at 50 while playing racquetball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mathew Brownstein
title: A ‘Plain-Spoken’ Way to Share Our Location
description: Datelines have announced the whereabouts of reporters for more than 150 years. The Times has introduced a change in the way it does that.
content: On April 14, 1912, a reporter sent a dispatch from HALIFAX, N.S. with breaking news: The White Star liner Titanic had struck an iceberg off the Newfoundland coast and was sinking. In 1926, a journalist wrote an article from the NORTH POLE for the first time. And in January 2020, New York Times journalists reported on a deadly new contagion — the coronavirus — from WUHAN, China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Breaking the Six-Feet Rule With Each Other
description: Natalie Warther and Ryan Dols were colleagues and then partners on projects before coming together for a pandemic-era romance.
content: Natalie Nicole Warther and Ryan Paul Dols worked at the same creative agency for years before partnering on projects. Little did they know that a professional connection would lead to a romantic one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Mary Turner Pattiz, Rock D.J. During FM’s Heyday, Dies at 76
description: She was known as “the Burner” for her seductive delivery, but off the air she was anything but a wild rock ’n’ roller. She later became an addiction counselor.
content: Mary Turner Pattiz, who as Mary Turner was a silky-voiced disc jockey at KMET, the album-oriented rock station that was the soundtrack of Southern California in the 1970s and early ’80s, before leaving radio to become an addiction counselor and philanthropist, died on May 9 at her home in Beverly Hills. She was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Hevesi
title: Ed Ames, Singing Star Who Became a Familiar Face on TV, Dies at 95
description: After more than a decade of hit records with his brothers, he found success as a solo performer and a star of the series “Daniel Boone.”
content: Ed Ames, who first gained fame as the lead singer of the Ames Brothers, a chart-topping group whose success predated the rise of rock ’n’ roll, and who then turned to acting as Fess Parker’s Indian companion on the popular NBC show “Daniel Boone,” died on Sunday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: The Inflation Debate Is Cooling
description: Weirdly, economists are starting to agree.
content: On Tuesday, the Brookings Institution held a special symposium on inflation, which I unfortunately couldn’t attend. But I read the two papers presented and some of the subsequent commentary, and it seems to me that something weird is happening: growing agreement among many (although not all) economists about both the causes of and, more important, the future prospects for inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: She Said Equinox Fired Her for Being a Black Woman. A Jury Agreed.
description: The high-end gym franchise was ordered to pay Röbynn Europe, a former employee, damages of $11.25 million.
content: Between 2018 and 2019, Röbynn Europe, a former professional body builder, worked at an Equinox on the Upper East Side, where she managed personal trainers. Years earlier, as a scholarship student at Brearley, the girls’ school several blocks away, where she began in seventh grade, commuting first from Canarsie and then Coney Island, she had experienced the coded bias of privileged teenagers. There was only one other Black student in her class. But still that had not prepared her for what she described as crass, unfiltered expressions of prejudice from male colleagues in an expensive gym, awash with the scent of eucalyptus oil if not the base notes of enlightenment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleni Schirmer and Louise Seamster
title: The Case Against Student Debt Relief Barely Even Pretends to Make Sense
description: A loan servicing agency looks to make more money, not less, if Biden’s plan goes into effect.
content: The Biden administration’s plan to cancel up to $20,000 of debt for tens of millions of Americans has faced endless pressure. Just this week the House of Representatives voted to repeal it. But the suit against it, brought by six Republican-led states, has received much less scrutiny. That’s because the Supreme Court issued certiorari before judgment, meaning the suit did not first have to wend its way through lower courts. Its factual claims haven’t been adequately tested. They’ve hardly even been aired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anastasia Tsioulcas
title: Review: Thanks to Chick Corea, the Trombone Is a Philharmonic Star
description: The jazz composer wrote a new concerto for the New York Philharmonic’s principal trombonist, Joseph Alessi, but died before its U.S. premiere.
content: There are not exactly a wealth of great concertos written for the trombone, that largely unheralded stalwart of the brass section. (Insert sad trombone sound here.) If anyone is going to change this state of affairs, it’s Joseph Alessi, the principal trombone of the New York Philharmonic. He’s an idol of legions of brass players for his rich tone, exemplary phrasing and virtuosic precision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sebastian Modak
title: From Subatomic Particles to the Cosmos, and Every Bird in Between
description: Five new audiobooks to download this summer include a breakdown of quantum computing and a tribute to Mary Oliver.
content: If you’d asked me a month ago what quantum theory was, I would have tried to answer only to stop myself once I realized that I didn’t actually know. It’s one of those concepts, like space-time or artificial intelligence, that many of us recognize (from science fiction, from the news) without ever really understanding them. That’s where QUANTUM SUPREMACY: How the Quantum Computer Revolution Will Change Everything (Random House Audio, 10 hours, 41 minutes), by the renowned translator of theoretical physics Michio Kaku, comes in. Named for the theoretical stage at which “a radically new type of computer, called a quantum computer, could decisively outperform an ordinary digital supercomputer on specific tasks,” the audiobook, read with deliberate — if at times robotic — clarity by Feodor Chin, begins with claims, by a handful of companies, that we are already there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ava Sasani
title: Indiana Reprimands Doctor Who Provided Abortion to 10-Year-Old Rape Victim
description: Dr. Caitlin Bernard violated the privacy of her young patient by discussing the girl’s case with a reporter, the state’s medical board ruled.
content: An Indiana doctor who provided an abortion to a 10-year-old rape victim last year violated her young patient’s privacy by discussing the case with a reporter, the state’s medical board ruled Thursday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison and Alan Rappeport
title: Debt Ceiling Crisis: How a Default Could Unfold
description: Here’s a look at what markets are expecting and planning for, and how a default might happen.
content: The United States is inching closer to calamity, as lawmakers continue to spar over what it will take to raise the country’s $31.4 trillion debt limit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: ‘The Little Mermaid’: 13 Differences Between the Original and Remake
description: It’s not just her voice Ariel loses in the new live-action adaptation. Plus, Sebastian has some updated advice in “Kiss the Girl.”
content: This article contains spoilers about the live-action version of “The Little Mermaid.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: The Celtics Finally Look Like They Want to Win
description: Boston hadn’t looked like the team that went to the N.B.A. finals last season — or like a team that wanted to get there this year.
content: Boston Celtics guard Marcus Smart is difficult to miss. His jump shot can be an amusement-park ride. He will try the occasional alley-oop pass from midcourt. He spoke earlier this month about the apparent brutality of a playoff game as a “true dogfight — scratching and clawing, biting, blood, everything.” He dyes his hair green.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Waite
title: When ‘Happily Ever After’ Is Just the Beginning
description: Our columnist recommends six dreamy new romance novels.
content: This summer I’m thinking about the “ever” part of “happily ever after.” An impossible span, considering that none of us are immortal. Romance novels are often scorned for being unrealistic — too many coincidences, too much wish fulfillment — but the most fantastical thing about the genre is how it thumbs its nose at time.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Joseph Henrich
description: The May 26, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Joseph Henrich. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Inside ‘May December,’ the Most Fun Film at Cannes
description: The movie stars Natalie Portman and Julianne Moore as cravenly self-interested women. Its director, Todd Haynes, is relieved that festival audiences are laughing.
content: At the Cannes Film Festival premiere of “May December” this week, something happened in the first few minutes that put director Todd Haynes at ease. It took place at the end of the movie’s second scene, as Gracie (Julianne Moore) gets ready for a family barbecue that will be attended by Elizabeth (Natalie Portman), a famous actress who is preparing to play Gracie in a film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Ban on Weight Discrimination Becomes Law in New York
description: The bill, signed by Mayor Eric Adams on Friday, adds weight to the list of characteristics protected from discrimination in areas like employment and housing.
content: Mayor Eric Adams on Friday signed into law a ban on discrimination in New York City based on a person’s weight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: More and More Teenagers Are Coming to School High, N.Y.C. Teachers Say
description: Students and teachers said in interviews that some classrooms were in disarray as more and younger students were smoking marijuana at school.
content: Ever since Justin, a 15-year-old high school freshman, tried marijuana on his birthday two years ago, he has smoked almost every day, several times a day, he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Extending an Olive Branch
description: Hemant Mehta opens our solving weekend.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Russian Public Appears to Be Souring on War Casualties, Analysis Shows
description: Support for the war in Ukraine remains high but could potentially turn if concern over the high numbers of casualties persists, according to FilterLabs AI.
content: Public sentiment in Russia over war casualties has been turning more negative during the intense fighting in recent months in eastern Ukraine, according to a new analysis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brittani Samuel
title: ‘Bernarda’s Daughters’ Review: Grieving a Father, and a Home
description: In her adaptation of Lorca, Diane Exavier emphasizes the importance of belonging to a place, and how painful it is to consign memories of it to the grave.
content: Federico García Lorca described his oft-adapted “La Casa de Bernarda Alba” simply as a “drama of women in the villages of Spain.” But as the Haitian American playwright Diane Exavier knows, whenever women gather — especially during times of mourning — there is always more at stake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Winnie the Pooh ‘Run, Hide, Fight’ Book Draws Parents’ Ire
description: The Dallas school district apologized for not providing guidance to parents when it sent students home with a book that teaches how to respond to dangerous situations at school.
content: The school district in Dallas has drawn backlash from parents after giving elementary school students a Winnie the Pooh-themed book that teaches children how to “run, hide, fight” in dangerous situations like a mass shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Reorienting Turkey’s Culture for His Own Ends
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 26, 2023.
content: “Everybody and his uncle is a nationalist in this country.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: If You’re Reading This, You’re Probably ‘WEIRD’
description: The anthropologist Joseph Henrich parses how culture shapes our psyches.
content: Here’s a little experiment. Take a second to think about how you would fill in the blank in this sentence: “I am _____.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Oshetsky
title: The Contagious, ‘Mild Vertigo’ of a Middle-Class Housewife
description: In Mieko Kanai’s 1997 novel, newly translated into English, a wife and mother’s monotonous days are punctured by quiet revelations.
content: By the end of the first, four-page-long sentence of “Mild Vertigo,” I found myself strongly identifying with Natsumi, the Tokyo housewife at the center of the Japanese author Mieko Kanai’s latest novel to be translated into English. Never mind that my life and Natsumi’s are nothing alike. Like her, I too began to fret about the cleanliness of my kitchen walls. My thoughts began to mimic the buzzy, galumphing rhythms of Natsumi’s interior world. I began to wonder whether I had always thought this way, whether this book was making me aware of the true nature of my mind for the first time. Such is the mesmerizing wonder of Kanai’s prose, as translated by Polly Barton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: In ‘Succession,’ the Very Rich Are Very, Very Different
description: The HBO drama, which ends on Sunday, updates past rich-people soaps like “Dallas.” But unlike those series, it argues that the problems of the hyper-wealthy inevitably become ours too.
content: On Nov. 21, 1980, more than 83 million people — over three-quarters of the entire American TV viewership — watched “Who Done It?,” the episode of “Dallas” that revealed who shot the love-to-hate-him oil magnate J.R. Ewing. The mystery, which CBS milked for eight solid months, was a consuming obsession, a Texas-sized example of the power of 20th-century TV to focus the world on one thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marina Harss
title: Exploring the Majesty and Mystery of Sor Juana in Dance
description: Michelle Manzanales’s new work for Ballet Hispánico is, she says, “a way of going personal through another person’s story.”
content: A dancer struggles and falls, again and again. She bends her back deeply and twists on the floor as the people around her watch, curious but withdrawn. We hear the sound of writing, graphite against paper. As couples pass by, the dancer leaps and rolls, flying and landing heavily, looking side to side as if seeking refuge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Gasoline Prices, a Source of Pain Last Year, Have Come Way Down
description: Reasons include a stronger supply of oil and weaker-than-expected demand, energy experts say. Some people are saving hundreds of dollars on fuel.
content: Americans who fill up their cars this Memorial Day weekend will catch a break — at least compared with a year ago, when gasoline prices were soaring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: What Are Your Plans This Summer?
description: What are you looking forward to doing when the school year ends?
content: What are you doing this summer? Are you working? Going on a trip? Attending a summer program or camp? Starting a new project? Hanging out with friends and family?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Out at Dusk
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration, or write about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Remembering Martin Amis
description: The Times critics Dwight Garner and Jason Zinoman celebrate the life and work of the great British novelist and literary critic, who died last week.
content: The writer Martin Amis, who died last week at the age of 73, was a towering figure of English literature. Practically born into the limelight, as the son of the celebrated British novelist Kingsley Amis, he secured his own fame in 1973 with the publication of his novel “The Rachel Papers,” and for the next half century went on to produce a scintillating body of ambitious, raucous, witty and stylish works of fiction and literary journalism distinguished by their cutting intelligence and virtuosic prose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theresa Rebeck
title: Why TV Finales Matter (And Why They Are So Hard to Get Right)
description: There’s a reason great TV endings are often the most elusive endings of all.
content: The ending of “Succession” is upon us. So how to end this bitter masterpiece?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Trussoni
title: Heads Exploding and ‘Bright Scarlet Ribbons Fountaining’
description: If your idea of a good summer read involves abject terror, we’ve got some recommendations for you.
content: Buried artifacts, lost treasures, ancient puzzles — archaeological excavations make for frightening fiction, especially when their unearthings wreak havoc on those living in the present. It’s easy to forget that Pazuzu — the demon who caused so much mischief in “The Exorcist” — emerged from an archaeological dig in Iraq.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: Among an Abundance of Bens, He Was the Best Bet
description: Shaina Shealy was dating three men, all with the same given name, but ditched two of them as she grew closer to Benjamin Glickstein just before the pandemic.
content: Shaina Schuster Shealy was dating three different men, all named Ben, in December 2019, when she needed a last-minute date to a work holiday party. She thought about who would be the least offended by an 11th-hour invitation and settled on Benjamin David Glickstein. He, unlike her, dated one person at a time, Mr. Glickstein said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: The Tangled Roots of Memorial Day and Why It’s Celebrated
description: The holiday marks the unofficial start of summer and honors those who have died in the nation’s wars. Here’s how it all began.
content: Memorial Day weekend is among the busiest for travel in the United States and the unofficial start of summer; a day for cookouts, beach trips and auto races. But how did Memorial Day, held on the last Monday of May in honor of America’s war dead, begin?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: Murder, They Wrote
description: Our columnist looks at a clutch of summer crime novels, including “I Didn’t Do It,” set at a mystery writers’ conference.
content: In my many years of attending crime and mystery writers’ conferences, the thought occurred to me — more than once — that they would make excellent settings for, well, murder. Jaime Lynn Hendricks takes this idea and runs with it in I DIDN’T DO IT (Scarlet, 325 pp., $26.95), her third suspense novel and one that entertainingly lays bare all kinds of writerly insecurities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully and William K. Rashbaum
title: Menendez Investigation Is Said to Involve Questions About Luxury Gifts
description: Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, has said he is confident the inquiry will “end up in absolutely nothing.”
content: Federal prosecutors and the F.B.I. are investigating whether Senator Robert Menendez or his wife received unreported gifts of a luxury car and an apartment in Washington from a halal meat company that is also the focus of a criminal inquiry, two people with knowledge of the matter said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen and Justin Porter
title: A Debt Deal May Be Near, but the Drama Is Not Over
description: Plus, how will “Succession” end? Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
content: After days of marathon sessions between House Republicans and the White House, negotiators are closing in on a deal and beginning to draft legislative text.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas, Alexandra Berzon and Jonathan Swan
title: DeSantis’s Administration Solicits Endorsements and Money for His Campaign
description: The appeals for endorsements from lawmakers and donations from lobbyists, which were described by several people familiar with the outreach, blur the line between the governor’s administration and his campaign.
content: As Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida begins his presidential bid, officials in his administration have solicited donations from lobbyists and endorsements from lawmakers in the state, blurring the line between his taxpayer-funded office and his political campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: F.B.I. Documents Detail 1983 Assassination Threat Against Queen Elizabeth II
description: A newly released trove of documents describe a threat to kill the queen during a visit that she and her husband made to the United States 40 years ago.
content: A trove of documents released this week by the F.B.I. reveal details about an assassination threat against Queen Elizabeth II before a trip that she and her husband made to the United States in 1983, as well as other security concerns linked to the Irish Republican Army.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Is a Debt Deal Nigh? The Market Sees Signs of Optimism.
description: Stock and bond trading suggest that investors see an imminent deal to raise the debt limit and prevent the federal government from defaulting.
content: Investors are holding their breath on Friday morning, amid signs that the White House and top House Republicans are closing in on a deal to raise the debt limit and avert a government default. Stock futures are showing modest gains, while yields on Treasury bills maturing on June 8 have fallen, suggesting bond traders expect an agreement soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Lazard Names Peter Orszag to Succeed Ken Jacobs as C.E.O.
description: Mr. Orszag will oversee a financial institution with a long history of advising on corporate deals at a time when its mainstay business faces huge challenges.
content: Lazard announced on Friday that Peter Orszag, who leads its core financial advisory business, will succeed Ken Jacobs as the company’s chief executive on Oct. 1. Mr. Jacobs will stay on as executive chairman and continue to advise clients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
description: We can almost guarantee you’ll get the willies this month with movies about thirsty bloodsuckers, famished flesh eaters and other frights.
content: This Spanish-language first feature from the Mexican director Michelle Garza Cervera covers familiar horror territory — mom trauma, folk brujeria — but puts a macabre, feminist refresh on worn formulas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christian Cooper
title: Three Years After a Fateful Day in Central Park, Birding Continues to Change My Life
description: Why — of all the spectacular creatures with which we share this planet — do birds captivate as no others can?
content: Early in the morning of May 25, 2020, I biked from my apartment on Manhattan’s Lower East Side to Central Park to go birding in the Ramble. Despite the uncertainties of the time — New Yorkers were living in a hot spot of the raging Covid pandemic, with no vaccine in sight — I strove to start this warm, sunlit Memorial Day on a happy note by wandering my favorite urban woodlands in search of migrating songbirds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Wagner group to leave Bakhmut.
content: Days after declaring victory in Bakhmut, the Wagner private military company said that it was turning the Ukrainian city over to the Russian Army, which must now try to hold on to it without the help of the brutal mercenary force on which it has grown dependent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: It’s Not Just the Debt Ceiling
description: A host of issues face the markets, beyond the prospect of a possible default on U.S. debt. Hedge your bets and ride it out, our columnist says.
content: On the surface, the stock market has been remarkably calm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Citi Bike, 10 Years Old and Part of New York’s Street Life
description: The bike-share service has grown and spread into more city neighborhoods, and it even had a cameo on “Succession.”
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at something that a transportation advocate told me was “an idea that seemed impossible, and now New York City can’t live without it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Houman Barekat
title: Review: Problematic Attachments in ‘Aspects of Love’
description: A London revival of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s partner-swapping musical is a camp amoral romp. But is this obsession really the same as romance?
content: For those who find regular love triangles too pedestrian, quadrangles and pentagons are also available. Unconventional arrangements are the order of the day in a dynamic revival of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “Aspects of Love,” which opened on Thursday at the Lyric Theater in London. This two-act musical, inspired by a 1955 novel by David Garnett, pits a young man against his uncle in a tussle for the affections of a mercurial actress; it is a camp, unapologetically amoral romp featuring blithe betrayals, intrafamilial partner-swapping and questionable intergenerational flirtations. (It is a lot raunchier than Lloyd Webber’s most recent work, which invited the audience to “sing unto the Lord with the harp” during the coronation of King Charles III.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Nina Feldman, Stella Tan, Liz O. Baylen, Rachel Quester, Diane Wong and Chris Wood
title: The Ticking Clock of a U.S. Debt Default
description: Time is running out for Congress to raise the debt limit. What are the prospects of a compromise in the negotiations?
content: Top White House officials and Republican lawmakers are racing to reach an agreement as the date when the United States is projected to default on its debt approaches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: Not Part of the Plan
description: “That’s why I picked a younger man; he wouldn’t do to me what your father did.”
content: In this week’s Modern Love essay, “That’s Why I Picked a Younger Man,” Conrad Gregory learns that trying to control the uncontrollable usually leads to pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens and Ofir Berman
title: Israel’s Unfinished Exodus Story
description: A flight from Addis Ababa to Tel Aviv reminds me of what it means to be Jewish.
content: JERUSALEM — When Sigal Kanotopsky was a child, her family left their mountain-ringed Jewish village in northern Ethiopia to make a five-and-a-half-week trek to Sudan. They traveled only at night for safety, using the cover of forests to sleep during the day. On the way the family lost Sigal’s 3-year-old brother, Negusie, and buried him by the side of the road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Counteroffensive Is Coming
description: We preview what is next in the war in Ukraine.
content: Retaking land occupied by an enemy during war is a brutally difficult task. But a military trying to do so usually has one big advantage: surprise. The occupying force does not know when or where the attackers will strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Consumer Spending Rose More Than Expected in April
description: New data on spending and income suggest that the economy remains robust despite the Federal Reserve’s interest rate increases.
content: Americans’ income and spending both rose in April, a sign of economic resilience amid rising prices and warnings of a possible recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: The Lakers Have Options. But LeBron James May Not Like Them All.
description: The Lakers can get back to the N.B.A. finals, but with James’s career almost over, some of the team’s possible strategies may take too long.
content: The day after the Los Angeles Lakers’ season ended in a sweep, General Manager Rob Pelinka told reporters that the team intended to “keep our core of young guys together.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Ashley Judd Reflects on a Year of Grief
description: The actress and mental health advocate shares how she coped while mourning the loss of her mother, the country music singer Naomi Judd, who died by suicide.
content: Every morning before getting out of bed, Ashley Judd pulls out a fountain pen and begins writing in her journal, a practice she has been doing for decades that she calls “the routine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: Two Premieres Reflect the Ups and Downs of a Major Flute Project
description: Claire Chase’s “Density 2036,” an undertaking to commission a new flute repertoire, reached its 10th installment with a multi-concert retrospective.
content: The flutist Claire Chase is a community builder. You can see this in “Density 2036,” her 24-year project to commission a new repertoire for her instrument. And you can sense a communal spirit when she offers gratitude to audiences who show up to several gigs in a row.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amal El-Mohtar
title: The Magic (and Malaise) of Families
description: New novels by Fonda Lee, Martha Wells, Nick Harkaway, Kelly Link and Emma Törzs.
content: Here are five extraordinary books about families — chosen, imposed or estranged — and the astonishing array of skills required to secure or survive them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Connie Chang
title: For a Better Workout, Trick Your Brain
description: Sometimes getting on the bike or hitting the pavement is more a mental game than a physical one.
content: We all know exercise is good for us, but its benefits don’t always motivate us to set an alarm and lace up our running shoes. According to the National Center for Health Statistics, 75 percent of Americans don’t meet the recommended guidelines for aerobic and strengthening exercise.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Battle of the SoHo Pergola and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
description: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: Traveling by Bus, Truck and Foot to Be Together
description: Vicmar Flores and Cullen Heater met in Panama City in 2017, and over the next couple of years traversed great distances to be with one another.
content: Vicmar Carolina Flores Hidalgo and Cullen Joseph Heater first crossed paths at a hostel in Panama City in late 2017. Mr. Heater, a Peace Corps volunteer from Milton, Mass., was recuperating there after ankle surgery. Ms. Flores, who moved to Panama from her native Venezuela a year earlier, was teaching yoga at the hostel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Boucher
title: Want to Be an Artist? You’re in Luck. This One Is Selling His Practice.
description: Darren Bader is looking to cap a two-decade artistic career by selling something valuable. Not the witty and poetic sculpture he’s known for, but his own name.
content: The phenomenon of the artist who drops out, whether only leaving the scene socially or actually ceasing to make work, may be as old as the scene itself, but it could be catching on. In 1967, Agnes Martin left New York for the New Mexico desert, avoiding the art world for years. In 1975, Bas Jan Ader disappeared after setting sail across the Atlantic alone in a tiny boat, giving rise to speculation about whether this was his final artistic gesture. Stanley Brouwn, Charlotte Posenenske and Lee Lozano have absented themselves, and, more recently, Cady Noland became legendary both for her work and for abandoning the art scene.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 26, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, May 26, 2023.
content: An article on Thursday about the ongoing political divide over gun policies misstated the number of Republicans who broke with their party to vote for the federal gun bill called the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act. Fifteen Republican senators voted for the bill, not 14.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Thompson
title: The Elusive Quest for Black Progress
description: Many measures of Black achievement in the U.S. have stalled or reversed. A series from Headway looks back at historical gains for their lessons today.
content: Life expectancy is one of the oldest and surest indicators we have of both human suffering and human progress. Wars, famines, the 1918 flu, vaccines, pasteurization, rising crop yields — so many events over time are encoded in the line of life expectancy, but its overall astonishing ascent is among the best cases for 20th-century humankind that can be made.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Ketamine Shows Promise for Hard-to-Treat Depression in New Study
description: Research this week presents the most robust evidence to date that ketamine is at least as effective as electroconvulsive therapy for patients with treatment-resistant depression who do not have psychosis.
content: A new study suggests that, for some patients, the anesthetic ketamine is a promising alternative to electroconvulsive therapy, or ECT, currently one of the quickest and most effective therapies for patients with difficult-to-treat depression. The study is the largest head-to-head comparison of the two treatments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: How the Crime of Seditious Conspiracy Is Different From Insurrection and Treason
description: A sentencing for a sedition conviction in the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol spotlights subtle differences within a suite of related criminal offenses.
content: At the heart of the case against Stewart Rhodes, the Oath Keepers leader who was sentenced on Thursday to the longest prison term yet in connection with the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, was a rare and serious charge: seditious conspiracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: The Designer Who Put Tina Turner in Those Hemlines
description: The long, spangly relationship between the singer and Bob Mackie.
content: The cardinal rule of dressing Tina Turner, the designer and costumer Bob Mackie said Wednesday night, was “you couldn’t cover anything up.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
title: On Erdogan Campaign Trail, Invoking God, Reciting Poetry, Bashing Foes
description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has rock star appeal at his election rallies, promising to lead Turkey to claim its rightful place as a global power if he is re-elected in a runoff on Sunday.
content: ISTANBUL — His campaign addresses begin softly, drawing the audience in. A devout Muslim, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan frequently says he seeks to please not just the Turkish people, but also God. Playing to the crowds, he sings folk songs, recites lines from local poets or drapes the sash of the local soccer team over his shoulders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery
title: Entry to Middle Class or False Promise? Franchises Face Scrutiny.
description: Troubles at the restaurant chain Burgerim highlight concerns about whether franchisees need more protection in their contracts with franchisers.
content: “Making It Work” is a series about small-business owners striving to endure hard times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: How Fighting for Conservative Causes Has Helped Ken Paxton Survive Legal Woes
description: With the Texas House set to vote on his impeachment, Mr. Paxton is counting on political support that he’s amassed as a Republican legal firebrand.
content: A decade ago, in a courthouse north of Dallas, a lawyer forgot his $1,000 Montblanc pen in a metal detector tray and returned to find that it had been taken. A review of surveillance footage turned up the culprit: Ken Paxton, who was a Texas state senator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Berlin Police Investigate Roger Waters After He Wore Nazi-Style Costumes at Concerts
description: Mr. Waters, a founder of Pink Floyd, who has long been critical of Israel, has worn similar clothing in the past when playing songs from Pink Floyd’s album “The Wall.”
content: The German police are investigating Roger Waters, a founder of the band Pink Floyd, who has long been critical of Israel, after he performed in Berlin last week wearing a Nazi-style costume like the one he used to critique fascism in “The Wall.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling and John Koblin
title: Predawn Picket Lines Help Writers Disrupt Studio Productions
description: Workers from other unions have shown solidarity with the strikers, catching entertainment companies off guard.
content: At 5 a.m. on a recent weekday, a lone figure paced back and forth outside the main entrance to the Fox Studios lot in Los Angeles. Peter Chiarelli, a screenwriter, was walking the picket line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Struggling to Attract Riders, BART Rethinks Its Service Schedule
description: The Bay Area transit agency, which has regained only 45 percent of its prepandemic ridership, will offer more service on nights and weekends.
content: It’s Friday. With ridership still less than half what it was before the pandemic began, BART is rethinking its service schedule. Plus, what are those strange new structures at Los Angeles bus stops?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Vineyard
title: ‘Succession’: 5 Questions We Have Heading Into the Finale
description: Will a Roy sibling emerge victorious? Is the Shivorce off? And what about American democracy? Here are some plot lines we are hoping to see resolved.
content: With few exceptions, the hit HBO series “Succession” has followed the “Seinfeld” model of “no hugging, no learning,” as the ultra-privileged Roy siblings seek to replace their late father, Logan (Brian Cox), at the top of the Waystar Royco media empire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Five Stand-Up Specials for the Long Holiday Weekend
description: Wanda Sykes, Sarah Silverman, Lewis Black, Zarna Garg and Greg Warren each deliver very funny hours worth your time.
content: Most comedy about the American immigrant family is related from the point of view of the assimilated son or daughter poking fun at the clueless, thick-accented parents. The beauty of our current moment is the many new perspectives on old jokes. In the fertile scene of South Asian comedians, Zarna Garg represents something fresh: the revenge of the Indian mom. She’s heard the jokes about the closed-minded Indian parents forcing their children to go to medical school. Now she fires back forcefully, with enough panache to subvert stereotypes even as she’s fully embracing them. Her ethnic and religious humor (she makes a convincing case for Hindu being the most chill religion) is unapologetically old-fashioned: quick setups, rapid-fire punchlines, her name in giant letters on the set behind her. There’s a genuine warmth behind the slickness. You believe her extreme pride in her daughter going to Stanford just as much as her operatic horror at the fact that she’s studying ceramics. Garg has the kind of presence that powers network sitcoms. Of the recent spate of specials produced by Amazon Prime, tentatively tiptoeing into competition with Netflix, hers is the best.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
description: Contemporary works by JG Thirlwell and Adolphus Hailstork, a Franz Schreker survey and a new recording by Michael Spyres are among the highlights.
content: If you’re a fan of adult cartoons, you may have already heard the music of the composer JG Thirlwell, who has written antic and entertaining themes for “Archer” and “The Venture Bros.” But he has also long plied his trade on the contemporary classical scene, with compositions for the Kronos Quartet and Alarm Will Sound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: A Kurdish Turkish Writer on the Tensions Between Politics and Art
description: Burhan Sönmez, who is president of PEN international, discusses the tension between politics and art and the role of literature in authoritarian societies.
content: The momentous Turkish presidential election, whose second round will take place on Sunday, has more than just geopolitical consequences; it is a watershed for culture as well. Since 2016, after a failed coup against President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the government here has cracked down on artists, writers, filmmakers and academics, who have experienced censorship, job losses and a climate of fear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ava Sasani
title: Judge Puts South Carolina Abortion Ban on Hold
description: The new law prohibited most abortions after six weeks, and was just signed into law.
content: A South Carolina judge on Friday temporarily blocked a new law restricting abortion access after six weeks of pregnancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: Belgian Aid Worker and Iranian Diplomat Freed in Prisoner Swap
description: The aid worker, Olivier Vandecasteele, had been sentenced to 40 years in prison for spying. The former diplomat was convicted of plotting a 2018 bomb attack.
content: Iran freed a Belgian aid worker imprisoned in Tehran for 455 days on charges of spying, in exchange for Belgium releasing a former Iranian diplomat who was convicted in 2021 of a thwarted bomb plot, officials from both countries said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin and J. David Goodman
title: Impeachment Vote Set for Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton: What to Know
description: The Texas House is set to vote on Saturday on the impeachment of Mr. Paxton, the culmination of years of official complaints and legal proceedings involving the three-term attorney general.
content: The Republican-dominated Texas House has scheduled a vote on the impeachment of the state’s Republican attorney general, Ken Paxton, for Saturday at 1 p.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: How a Novel About Video Games Became a Surprise Best Seller
description: Gabrielle Zevin didn’t expect a wide audience for “Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow,” her novel about game developers. It became a blockbuster with staying power.
content: Five and a half years ago, Gabrielle Zevin was in a slump. She had recently published her ninth novel, and sales were sluggish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Hennessy
title: For a Chile Con Queso Like No Other, Head to Southern New Mexico
description: At Chope’s Town Bar & Cafe, one family has closely guarded a recipe that makes the most of the region’s beloved chiles.
content: The chile con queso you know best may be a jar of tomato- and chile-flecked processed cheese. But it can also be a thing of unparalleled beauty, a deliciously messy, fiery, thin salsa capped with molten cheese meant to be pinched with fresh tortillas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Koba Ryckewaert
title: Students in Belgium Hazing Death Are Sentenced to Fines and Service
description: Sanda Dia, a 20-year-old Black student at the Catholic University of Leuven, died in 2018 after members of an elite fraternity forced him to drink fish oil, swallow goldfish and stand in an ice-filled trench.
content: Eighteen students who put a young Black man through a notorious fraternity hazing ritual at a prestigious university in Belgium, leading to his death and setting off a national debate about racism, were convicted of involuntary manslaughter on Friday and ordered to pay fines and perform community service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Colleges Will Be Able to Hide a Student’s Race on Admissions Applications
description: If requested, the Common App will conceal basic information on race and ethnicity — a move that could help schools if the Supreme Court ends affirmative action.
content: Each year, the million or so students applying to college through the Common App are given the option to check a box, disclosing whether they identify as Hispanic, Asian, Black or white, among other choices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Russians Hit Ukrainian Hospital as Both Sides Step Up Long-Range Strikes
description: A Russian missile killed at least two people and wounded dozens more at a hospital, while apparent Ukrainian strikes hit occupied cities in the south.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Explosions far behind the front lines shook Ukraine on Friday, as a Russian missile demolished part of a hospital complex and apparent Ukrainian strikes hit Russian-occupied cities, in their escalating, long-range aerial war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: My Fantasy Bookshelf
description: Vacation readings of mythic proportions.
content: After filing last week’s newsletter comparing “Succession” to a work of “Game of Thrones”-style fantasy, I recorded a podcast episode with Razib Khan in which we talked about our shared affection for actual fantasy novels, our experience as early George R.R. Martin adopters and other matters of deep nerd interest. It was a wide-ranging conversation, but one that stayed mostly with the big names of the genre — Martin, J.R.R. Tolkien, a few others — rather than offering a detailed list of reading recommendations. So since we’re headed into a holiday weekend and everyone needs a true break from politics, I thought I’d offer a short list of novels for anyone interested in the kinds of things fantasy does well and looking for almost-summer entertainment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo and Ben Casselman
title: Inflation Inched Higher in April, Reflecting Challenge for the Fed
description: The Federal Reserve’s preferred inflation gauge, the Personal Consumption Expenditures index, climbed 4.4 percent in April, a slight increase from March.
content: A measure of inflation most closely watched by Federal Reserve officials picked up in April, reflecting the difficult path ahead for economic policymakers as they weigh whether to raise interest rates again to bring down stubborn price increases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Cheese Croutons, Bulgogi Burgers and Crispy Rice
description: In other words: orecchiette salad with crisped halloumi, Korean cheeseburgers with sesame pickles and one-pan Iranian rice and runny eggs.
content: My job is to write to you about weeknight recipes, the dishes you can make at the end of a long day when you don’t have much time or energy, but still want something good to eat. But I’m a dessert person, and so first I must direct your attention to Melissa Clark’s new strawberry recipes, especially this strawberry cream cheese tart. Perfect for the long weekend!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: For Ukraine Military, Far-Right Russian Volunteers Make for Worrisome Allies
description: Some fighters who led an incursion into Russian territory this week have neo-Nazi ties. “I worry that something like this could backfire on Ukraine because these are not ambiguous people.”
content: A group of fighters aligned with Ukraine, who had participated earlier this week in the most intense fighting inside Russia’s borders since the invasion, gathered the foreign and local press in an undisclosed location on Wednesday to celebrate, to taunt the Kremlin and to show off what they called “military trophies” from their incursion into their native land: Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Summer Is Coming. It’s Time to Check Your Feet.
description: Podiatrists suggest examining your feet year-round and implementing a few other habits during warmer months.
content: For the past few months, my feet have been sheathed in socks and slippers — like cave fish, hidden from the light. With summer around the corner, though, it’s time for them to emerge. In preparation, I carefully inspect every inch of my feet to ensure they are ready to show to the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Amber Bracken
title: Alberta Election Tests Conservatives’ Hard-Right Turn
description: The pandemic took the conservative party in the oil-rich province of Alberta far to the right. An election on Monday will test if voters, traditionally among Canada’s most conservative, will follow.
content: Sitting at a cafe terrace overlooking a park commemorating the birthplace of the vast oil industry in the western Canadian province of Alberta, Audrey Cerkvenac and Ernestine Dumont, wrestled with a political dilemma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Treasury Expects to Run Out of Cash by June 5
description: The latest estimate comes as Republicans and the White House are trying to reach an agreement to raise the debt ceiling and avoid a crippling default.
content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said on Friday that the United States will run out of money to pay its bills on time by June 5, moving the goal post back slightly while maintaining the urgency for congressional leaders to reach a deal to raise or suspend the debt limit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tala Safie
title: How Well Do You Know ‘Succession’?
description: This is not a personality quiz.
content: This is not a personality quiz.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Inside the Grassroots Granny Network That Helps Migrants
description: A state of emergency has been declared in several counties north of New York City because of the arrivals of migrants, which has inspired one nonprofit to spring into action.
content: A state of emergency has been declared in several counties north of New York City because of the arrivals of migrants, which has inspired one nonprofit to spring into action.

description: Fire heavily damaged a clinic in Dnipro, Ukraine, after a Russian strike hit the building.
